text: Publication bias — the tendency for studies with significant or positive results to be more readily published — is a major threat to the validity of any meta-analysis. We used multiple complementary approaches to detect and adjust for potential publication bias.

4.2 Trim-and-Fill
The Duval and Tweedie trim-and-fill method imputed 11 missing studies and reduced the pooled estimate from OR = 2.18 to OR = 1.50 (95% CI: 1.15–1.96). The adjusted estimate remained statistically significant, suggesting that even after accounting for potentially missing studies, shorter TTP is associated with increased mortality.


4.3 Frequentist Selection Model






NoteExtreme Adjustment with Sparse Data



The frequentist step-function selection model estimated δ = 0.037, meaning non-significant studies had only a 3.7% probability of being observed relative to significant studies. This extreme selection parameter pushed the adjusted OR to 1.09 (95% CI: 0.67–1.79), rendering the association non-significant.
However, this result should be interpreted with caution: with only 3 non-significant studies, the maximum likelihood estimator for δ is unstable and tends toward extreme values.




4.4 Bayesian Selection Models
To address the limitations of frequentist selection models with sparse non-significant data, we implemented fully Bayesian step-function selection models in Stan.
Two prior specifications for the selection parameter δ:

ImportantKey Finding: Robust to Publication Bias



Both Bayesian selection models yielded pooled ORs of ~2.14 with P(OR > 1) = 100%, essentially unchanged from the unadjusted estimate. This occurs because the Bayesian framework:

Regularizes the selection parameter away from extreme values
Propagates uncertainty about the degree of selection into the pooled estimate
Avoids overfitting to the sparse non-significant study data

title: Publication Bias
text:
5 Why the Discrepancy Between Approaches?








Figure 2: Comparison of pooled odds ratios across publication bias adjustment methods. Error bars show 95% CI or CrI.





The discrepancy between frequentist and Bayesian selection models arises from the data characteristics:

Only 9% non-significant studies — the frequentist MLE has very little data to estimate the selection function, leading to extreme parameter values (δ → 0)
Bayesian priors regularize — even the uninformative Uniform(0,1) prior provides enough regularization to avoid the extreme adjustment
91% significance rate — this rate is higher than expected even for a large true effect, but the Bayesian approach accounts for uncertainty about why

title: Publication Bias
text:
6 Interpretation and Conclusions

6.1 Balanced Assessment
Evidence for publication bias:

Significant funnel asymmetry (Egger’s p < 0.001)
Deficit of small non-significant studies
91% of studies are statistically significant

Evidence for a real effect despite bias:

All Bayesian models confirm OR > 1 with 100% posterior probability
Trim-and-fill adjusted estimate (OR = 1.50) remains significant
The effect is consistent across study quality levels and subgroups
Large studies also show positive associations

Best estimate of the true effect:
The true effect likely lies between OR = 1.50 (trim-and-fill, conservative lower bound) and OR = 2.14 (Bayesian primary estimate). The frequentist selection model estimate of 1.09 likely represents over-adjustment.
Short TTP is robustly associated with increased mortality across all analytical approaches except the most extreme frequentist correction, which is unreliable with sparse non-significant studies.

title: Methods
text:
2 Effect Size Computation

2.1 Hierarchy of Effect Estimates
Effect sizes were computed following this priority hierarchy:

Reported adjusted estimates (OR/HR/RR with CI) — preferred
Reported unadjusted estimates (OR/HR/RR with CI)
Computed from 2×2 tables using metafor::escalc()
Continuous TTP effects (OR per hour) — analyzed separately



2.2 Standardization to Log-Odds Ratios
All effect estimates were converted to log-odds ratios (log-OR) with sampling variances:
From 2×2 tables:

escalc(
  measure = "OR",
  ai = events_short_ttp,
  bi = n_short_ttp - events_short_ttp,
  ci = events_long_ttp,
  di = n_long_ttp - events_long_ttp
)

From reported OR/HR/RR with 95% CI:

yi = log(effect_estimate)
sei = (log(ci_upper) - log(ci_lower)) / (2 * 1.96)
vi = sei^2



2.3 Deduplication Rules
When multiple effect estimates were available from the same study:

Prefer adjusted over unadjusted (Cilloniz2017, Hou2023)
Remove extreme sparse-cell estimates (Melling2019 OR = 1722)
Keep legitimate subgroups (Marco2025 — two distinct populations)

title: Methods
text:
3 Statistical Analysis

3.1 Primary Model: Bayesian Random-Effects
We fit Bayesian hierarchical models using brms:

brm(
  yi | se(sei) ~ 1 + (1 | study_id),
  data = es_data,
  prior = c(
    prior(normal(0, 1), class = "Intercept"),
    prior(cauchy(0, 0.5), class = "sd")
  ),
  backend = "cmdstanr",
  chains = 4, 
  iter = 4000, 
  warmup = 1000,
  control = list(adapt_delta = 0.95)
)



3.2 Prior Specification Rationale






NoteWeakly Informative Priors



Intercept: Normal(0, 1)
- On log-OR scale - 95% prior mass: OR ∈ [0.14, 7.4] - Compatible with wide range of clinically plausible effects
Between-study SD (τ): Half-Cauchy(0, 0.5)
- Allows moderate to substantial heterogeneity - Regularizes extreme values - Recommended by Gelman (2006) for hierarchical models




3.3 Validation: Frequentist REML
Frequentist random-effects models via metafor provided convergence validation:

rma(yi = yi, vi = vi, data = es_data, method = "REML")



3.4 Meta-Regression
Univariable meta-regressions tested prespecified moderators:

brm(
  yi | se(sei) ~ 1 + moderator + (1 | study_id),
  prior = c(
    prior(normal(0, 1), class = "Intercept"),
    prior(normal(0, 0.5), class = "b"),  # moderator effects
    prior(cauchy(0, 0.5), class = "sd")
  ),
  ...
)

Moderators examined:

Pathogen class (Gram-positive vs Gram-negative)
Staphylococcus aureus vs other organisms
Risk of bias (low vs moderate/high)
Blood culture system (BACTEC vs BacTALERT vs other)
TTP cutpoint (continuous, where available)

5.1 Outlier Exclusion
Studies with extreme effect sizes were identified and excluded:

Mortality: Ji2020 (OR = 40.45)
Persistent bacteremia: Melling2019 (OR = 37), Kassis2009 (OR = 75)



5.2 Prior Sensitivity
We tested four prior specifications for the mortality analysis:

Primary: Normal(0, 1) + Half-Cauchy(0, 0.5)
Wide: Normal(0, 2) + Half-Cauchy(0, 0.5)
Skeptical: Normal(0, 0.5) + Half-Cauchy(0, 0.5)
Half-Normal τ: Normal(0, 1) + Half-Normal(0, 0.5)

title: Time to Positivity & Clinical Outcomes in Bacteremia
text: This comprehensive meta-analysis examines whether shorter blood culture time to positivity (TTP) predicts worse clinical outcomes in patients with bacteremia.

title: Time to Positivity & Clinical Outcomes in Bacteremia
text:
1.1 Executive Summary
Blood culture time to positivity (TTP) — the interval between culture incubation and microbial growth detection — has emerged as a potential prognostic marker in bacteremia. Shorter TTP is hypothesized to reflect higher bacterial inocula, which may signal more severe infection and increased risk of adverse outcomes.

1.1.1 Primary Findings


1.1.2 Mortality
Pooled OR: 2.14 (95% CrI: 1.69–2.79)
Based on 33 studies with P(OR > 1) = 100%


1.1.3 Persistent Bacteremia
Pooled OR: 4.02 (95% CrI: 1.08–11.11)
Based on 7 studies with P(OR > 1) = 97.9%


Key Finding: Short TTP is robustly associated with increased mortality risk. The association remains significant across all sensitivity analyses, prior specifications, and publication bias adjustment methods.

1.4 Analytical Approach

1.4.1 Bayesian Framework
We employed a Bayesian random-effects framework using brms with weakly informative priors:

Pooled effect (μ): Normal(0, 1) prior on log-OR scale
Between-study heterogeneity (τ): Half-Cauchy(0, 0.5)
MCMC: 4 chains, 4000 iterations (1000 warmup)

Frequentist REML models via metafor provided validation.


1.4.2 Key Analyses

✅ Random-effects meta-analysis (Bayesian & frequentist)
✅ Publication bias assessment (funnel plots, Egger’s test, trim-and-fill, selection models)
✅ Sensitivity analyses (outlier exclusion, prior sensitivity)
✅ Meta-regression (pathogen, organism, risk of bias, blood culture system)
✅ Risk of bias assessment (6 domains, 45 studies)

title: Risk of Bias
text:
4 Domain-Specific Assessment








Figure 2: Stacked bar chart showing the proportion of studies rated as low, moderate, or high risk for each assessment domain.






4.1 Domain-Specific Observations
Selection: Most studies used consecutive or clearly defined patient populations from hospital microbiology databases, resulting in generally low risk for selection bias.
Comparability: This was the most common source of concern. Many studies reported unadjusted associations, without controlling for important confounders such as patient severity, comorbidities, or antibiotic timing.
Outcome: Mortality outcomes were generally well-ascertained through hospital records or national death registries. Persistent bacteremia definitions varied more across studies.
Statistical Analysis: Studies varied from simple chi-squared tests to multivariable logistic regression. Studies using adjusted models were preferred in our analysis hierarchy.
Attrition: Most studies were retrospective cohorts with complete follow-up data from electronic medical records, resulting in low attrition risk.
Prognostic Measurement: All studies used automated blood culture detection systems (BACTEC or BacT/ALERT), providing standardized, objective TTP measurements.

title: Risk of Bias
text:
5 Impact on Meta-Analysis Results






ImportantRisk of Bias Does Not Modify the Association



Meta-regression testing risk of bias as a moderator showed no significant effect (β = -0.08, 95% CrI: -0.55 to 0.39). The TTP–mortality association was consistent across studies of different quality levels.
This provides reassurance that:

The pooled estimate is not inflated by low-quality studies
Methodological limitations do not explain the observed association
The finding is robust to study quality variations

title: Risk of Bias
text:
7 Limitations
While the overall quality profile is encouraging, several methodological concerns are common across the literature:

Retrospective design: Most studies were retrospective cohorts, limiting control over confounding
Variable TTP cutpoints: No standardized threshold exists, making direct comparison challenging
Limited adjustment: Many studies reported unadjusted associations
Single-center designs: Most studies were from single institutions, potentially limiting generalizability
Publication bias: Studies with positive results may be overrepresented (see Publication Bias)


For the impact of publication bias on our findings, see Publication Bias. For pooled estimates, see Results.

title: Discussion & Conclusions
text:
This Bayesian meta-analysis synthesized data from 42 effect sizes across 40 unique studies to evaluate whether blood culture time to positivity (TTP) predicts clinical outcomes in patients with bacteremia.



1. Short TTP strongly predicts increased mortality
The pooled odds ratio was 2.14 (95% CrI: 1.69–2.79) with P(OR > 1) = 100%, indicating virtual posterior certainty that shorter TTP is associated with higher mortality risk. This finding was consistent across Bayesian and frequentist frameworks, and robust to sensitivity analyses including outlier exclusion and prior specification changes.


2. Short TTP predicts persistent bacteremia
The association was even stronger for microbiological failure, with a pooled OR of 4.02 (95% CrI: 1.08–11.11, P(OR > 1) = 97.9%). Though based on fewer studies (k = 7–9), this finding suggests that higher bacterial inocula predict difficulty achieving bloodstream clearance.


3. TTP is a pathogen-agnostic prognostic marker
Stratified analysis showed virtually identical associations for Gram-positive (OR = 2.17) and Gram-negative (OR = 2.06) infections, with only a 57.7% posterior probability of any difference between groups. This means TTP can inform clinical decisions immediately upon culture positivity, before organism identification is complete.

title: Discussion & Conclusions
text:
2 Clinical Implications

2.1 For Bedside Clinicians
Short TTP identifies patients at substantially elevated risk of adverse outcomes. Practical applications include:

Early risk stratification. Upon receiving a positive blood culture result, clinicians can check the TTP. Patients with TTP below 10–12 hours warrant heightened vigilance and potentially earlier escalation of care.
Monitoring intensity. Short-TTP patients may benefit from more frequent hemodynamic monitoring, earlier repeat cultures to assess clearance, and closer follow-up for complications.
Treatment decisions. While TTP alone should not dictate antibiotic choices, it can complement clinical assessment in decisions about source control urgency, the need for combination therapy, or ICU-level care.
Prognostic communication. TTP provides an objective, easily communicated marker for discussing prognosis with patients, families, and colleagues.



2.2 For Microbiologists and Laboratory Medicine

Reporting practices. Routine reporting of TTP alongside culture results could enhance the clinical utility of blood culture data without additional cost.
System calibration. While the association was consistent across blood culture systems (BACTEC, BacT/ALERT), standardization of how TTP is recorded and communicated would improve its clinical utility.
Cutpoint standardization. Our meta-regression suggests that cutpoints around 10–12 hours may offer the strongest prognostic signal. Laboratories should consider adopting standardized reporting thresholds.



2.3 For Researchers

Cutpoint optimization. The borderline meta-regression trend for TTP cutpoint (β = -0.032/hour, P = 96.1%) indicates that identifying the optimal prognostic threshold is a priority research question.
Persistent bacteremia. More studies with consistent outcome definitions are needed for this important endpoint. The current evidence (k = 7–9) is suggestive but limited.
Dose-response analyses. Future studies should report both continuous and dichotomized TTP data to enable dose-response modeling and identify nonlinear thresholds.
Confounding control. Studies should adjust for key confounders including illness severity scores, time to appropriate antibiotics, source control status, and immunosuppression.

title: Discussion & Conclusions
text:
3 Strengths
This meta-analysis has several important methodological strengths:

Comprehensive search. The analysis includes 57 studies with 88 outcome records, representing the largest synthesis of TTP–outcome evidence to date.
Bayesian framework. The use of Bayesian random-effects models with weakly informative priors provides probabilistic statements about the association (e.g., P(OR > 1) = 100%), avoids dichotomous significant/non-significant classifications, and handles small sample sizes more appropriately.
Rigorous effect size hierarchy. The analysis preferentially used adjusted effect estimates and applied clear deduplication rules to avoid double-counting.
Extensive sensitivity analyses. Results were tested against outlier exclusion, prior sensitivity, risk of bias exclusions, and multiple publication bias adjustment methods (trim-and-fill, frequentist selection, Bayesian selection models).
Pathogen stratification. The novel pathogen-specific analysis demonstrates the generalizability of TTP as a prognostic marker across organism types.

title: Discussion & Conclusions
text:
4 Limitations






WarningKey Limitations




Substantial heterogeneity (I² = 99.3%) that was not explained by any prespecified moderator. Unmeasured factors (patient severity, antibiotic timing, source control) likely contribute.
Variable TTP cutpoints across studies (range: 8–72 hours) limit direct comparability and may contribute to heterogeneity.
Observational study designs cannot establish causality. Short TTP may be a marker of disease severity rather than a direct cause of poor outcomes.
Evidence of publication bias with significant funnel asymmetry (Egger’s p < 0.001). While Bayesian selection models suggest the effect is robust, the true magnitude may be somewhat smaller than the primary estimate.
Limited persistent bacteremia data (k = 7–9) with influential outliers makes conclusions for this outcome less certain.
Predominantly retrospective cohorts from single academic centers may limit generalizability to other healthcare settings.

title: Discussion & Conclusions
text:
5 Comparison with Prior Syntheses
This analysis substantially extends previous reviews by including more studies, employing Bayesian methods, and providing pathogen-specific estimates. The core finding — that short TTP predicts worse outcomes — is consistent with the prior understanding, but our analysis provides more precise estimates and stronger evidence for pathogen independence.

title: Discussion & Conclusions
text:
6 Conclusions






ImportantBottom Line



Short blood culture time to positivity is a robust, pathogen-agnostic prognostic marker in bacteremia. Patients with shorter TTP have approximately twice the odds of mortality (OR = 2.14, 95% CrI: 1.69–2.79) and four times the odds of persistent bacteremia (OR = 4.02, 95% CrI: 1.08–11.11).
This readily available laboratory parameter deserves routine clinical attention and could contribute to early risk stratification, potentially improving care for one of the most common and deadly infectious syndromes.

title: Discussion & Conclusions
text:
7 Future Directions

Prospective validation studies with standardized TTP cutpoints (preferably 10–12 hours) and predefined outcome definitions
Individual patient data meta-analysis to model the dose-response relationship and optimize cutpoints
Integration studies examining TTP within multivariate prediction models alongside severity scores and biomarkers
Interventional trials testing whether TTP-guided management (e.g., early escalation protocols for short-TTP patients) improves clinical outcomes
Economic analyses evaluating the cost-effectiveness of TTP-based risk stratification


Citation: Lewis R. Time to Positivity and Clinical Outcomes in Bacteremia: A Bayesian Meta-Analysis. 2026.
Last Updated: February 2026

2.2 Key Findings






ImportantMain Result



Shorter TTP is associated with significantly increased mortality with a Bayesian pooled odds ratio of 2.14 (95% CrI: 1.69–2.79).
The probability that the true OR is greater than 1 is 100%, indicating virtual certainty of a positive association.


Clinical Interpretation:

Patients with shorter TTP (reflecting higher bacterial inocula) have approximately 2× higher odds of mortality compared to those with longer TTP
This association is consistent across diverse patient populations and pathogens
The finding provides strong evidence that TTP is a clinically meaningful prognostic marker in bacteremia

The Bayesian and frequentist approaches yield nearly identical point estimates, providing strong validation of the robustness of our findings.


2.4 Heterogeneity
The substantial between-study heterogeneity (τ = 0.58, I² = 89.1%) suggests variability in effect sizes across studies. This heterogeneity may be attributable to:

Different TTP cutpoints used across studies
Variation in patient severity and comorbidity burden
Differences in pathogen distributions
Variable timing of appropriate antibiotic therapy
Quality of source control procedures

Meta-regression analyses (see Meta-Regression page) were conducted to explore sources of heterogeneity.

The association between shorter TTP and persistent bacteremia is even stronger than for mortality, though based on fewer studies (k = 2). This suggests that higher bacterial inocula (reflected by shorter TTP) may predict both difficulty in achieving bacterial clearance and worse clinical outcomes.

title: Meta-Regression
text:
3 Meta-Regression Models

3.1 Bayesian Meta-Regression Specification
Each moderator was tested in a separate univariable meta-regression:

brm(
  yi | se(sei) ~ 1 + moderator + (1 | study_id),
  prior = c(
    prior(normal(0, 1), class = "Intercept"),
    prior(normal(0, 0.5), class = "b"),
    prior(cauchy(0, 0.5), class = "sd")
  ),
  backend = "cmdstanr",
  chains = 4, iter = 4000, warmup = 1000,
  control = list(adapt_delta = 0.95)
)

The moderator effect prior Normal(0, 0.5) is mildly regularizing — it centers at zero (no moderator effect) with 95% prior mass allowing log-OR differences of up to ±1.0 between levels.

4.2 Pathogen Class






TipNo Pathogen Difference



The TTP–mortality association was virtually identical for Gram-positive (OR = 2.17, 95% CrI: 1.52–3.36) and Gram-negative infections (OR = 2.06, 95% CrI: 1.48–3.15). The ratio of odds ratios was 1.05 (95% CrI: 0.61–1.83), with only a 57.7% posterior probability of any difference.
Clinical implication: TTP can be used as a prognostic marker immediately upon culture positivity, regardless of Gram stain result.




4.3 S. aureus vs Other Organisms
Studies focused exclusively on S. aureus bacteremia showed a slightly stronger association (β = 0.12 log-OR), but this difference was not statistically meaningful (95% CrI: -0.38 to 0.62). The TTP signal is not driven by any single pathogen.


4.4 Risk of Bias
Study quality did not moderate the TTP–mortality association (β = -0.08, 95% CrI: -0.55 to 0.39). This means:

The effect is not inflated by low-quality studies
Both low and moderate-risk studies report similar associations
The finding is robust to methodological quality variations



4.5 Blood Culture System
Different automated blood culture systems (BACTEC, BacT/ALERT, and others) use different detection algorithms, which could theoretically affect TTP measurements. However, the system type did not significantly moderate the association (β = 0.15, 95% CrI: -0.42 to 0.72).


4.6 TTP Cutpoint






WarningBorderline Trend for TTP Cutpoint



The TTP cutpoint showed the strongest trend among moderators, with a coefficient of -0.032 log-OR per hour (95% CrI: -0.068 to 0.004). This suggests:

Lower cutpoints (e.g., ≤10–12 hours) may capture a stronger signal
Higher cutpoints (e.g., ≥48 hours) may dilute the prognostic value
The posterior probability of a negative slope was 96.1% — suggestive but not conclusive

This finding has practical implications for future study design: TTP cutpoints of 10–12 hours may optimize prognostic discrimination.










Figure 1: Meta-regression of log-OR against TTP cutpoint (hours). The negative trend suggests stronger associations at lower cutpoints.

title: Meta-Regression
text:
5 Heterogeneity Not Explained






ImportantKey Finding



No single prespecified moderator significantly explained between-study heterogeneity. The residual τ remained virtually unchanged (0.49–0.58) across all meta-regression models compared to the unadjusted model (τ = 0.58).
This suggests the observed heterogeneity likely arises from unmeasured factors such as:

Patient severity and comorbidity burden
Timing of appropriate antibiotic therapy
Source control practices
Variation in healthcare settings and critical care protocols
Differences in TTP measurement protocols within systems

title: Meta-Regression
text:
6 Implications
The meta-regression findings support two important conclusions:

Generalizability: The TTP–mortality association is consistent across pathogen types, blood culture systems, study quality levels, and organism subtypes. This supports its use as a general prognostic marker in bacteremia.
Future research priorities: The borderline cutpoint trend (β = -0.032/hour) suggests that optimizing the TTP threshold is an important research question. Studies should focus on identifying the optimal cutpoint through receiver operating characteristic (ROC) analyses or similar approaches.


For pooled estimates and forest plots, see Results and Forest Plots.

forest(rma_mort,
       slab = es_mort$study_id[!is.na(es_mort$yi)],
       atransf = exp,
       xlab = "Odds Ratio (log scale)",
       header = c("Study", "OR [95% CI]"),
       cex = 0.8,
       xlim = c(-6, 8),
       at = log(c(0.1, 0.25, 0.5, 1, 2, 4, 8, 16)),
       refline = 0,
       ilab.xpos = -4,
       fonts = "sans")

# Add text
text(-6, -1, "Favors Longer TTP", pos = 4, cex = 0.8, font = 3)
text(8, -1, "Favors Shorter TTP", pos = 2, cex = 0.8, font = 3)








Figure 1: Forest plot of mortality outcomes. Each row represents a single study with the point estimate (square) and 95% confidence interval (horizontal line). The size of the square is proportional to the study weight. The diamond at the bottom represents the pooled random-effects estimate.





The forest plot above shows:

Individual study estimates: Each study’s odds ratio and 95% confidence interval
Study weights: Larger squares indicate studies with greater precision (smaller standard errors) that contribute more to the pooled estimate
Pooled estimate: The diamond at the bottom represents the random-effects meta-analytic estimate
Reference line: The vertical dashed line at OR = 1 indicates no association







NoteInterpretation



Most studies fall to the right of the null line (OR = 1), indicating that shorter TTP is consistently associated with increased mortality across diverse populations and settings. The pooled estimate (diamond) clearly excludes 1.0, confirming a significant association.

text:
4 Funnel Plot for Publication Bias


Show code
# Create funnel plot
funnel(rma_mort, 
       atransf = exp,
       xlab = "Odds Ratio",
       main = "Funnel Plot - Mortality Outcome",
       back = "white",
       shade = "white",
       hlines = "gray")

# Add trim-and-fill points if applicable
taf <- trimfill(rma_mort)
if (taf$k0 > 0) {
  points(exp(taf$yi), 1/sqrt(taf$vi), pch = 19, col = "red", cex = 0.8)
  legend("topright", 
         legend = c("Observed studies", "Imputed studies (trim-and-fill)"),
         pch = 19,
         col = c("black", "red"),
         cex = 0.8)
}








Figure 4: Funnel plot for mortality studies. Asymmetry suggests potential publication bias or small-study effects.





The funnel plot shows asymmetry with a deficit of small studies showing null or protective effects. This pattern suggests:

Possible publication bias: Studies with null findings may be underrepresented
Small-study effects: Smaller studies tend to report larger effect sizes
Genuine heterogeneity: Different study populations or methods

See the Publication Bias page for detailed sensitivity analyses addressing these concerns.

  ) +

Figure 5: Distribution of observed effect sizes across mortality studies.





The distribution shows:

Most studies report OR > 1 (harmful effect of shorter TTP)
Effect sizes range from approximately 0.5 to 16
The majority cluster between OR = 1.5 and 4.0
Very few studies show protective effects (OR < 1)

title: Forest Plots
text:
6 Summary
These forest plots demonstrate:

Consistent directionality: The vast majority of studies show shorter TTP associated with worse outcomes
Statistical significance: The pooled estimates clearly exclude the null value
Pathogen-agnostic effect: Similar associations across Gram-positive and Gram-negative infections
Stronger effect for persistent bacteremia: Suggesting TTP predicts both clinical and microbiological outcomes
Potential publication bias: Asymmetric funnel plot warrants sensitivity analyses

For more details on heterogeneity and moderator analyses, see Meta-Regression.
